instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.USBC_XA_CC2: What is USBC_XA_CC2? USBC_XA_CC2 is a line between the USB-C muxing chip such as the CD3217 or CD3215 and the USB-C charger. Communication must happen on this line in order for the USB-C charger to put out 20v..
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_BMON: What is CHGR_BMON? CHGR_BMON goes between the ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 that charges the battery & creates PPBUS_G3H and the SMC(system management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip) and provides current sensing information on battery charging to the SMC. If diagnostics reveal an off reading or failure with the charger current sense, this is a good place to start troubleshooting..
definitions.CHGR_AMON: What is CHGR_AMON? CHGR_AMON provides DC current sense information to the SMC(System management controller) or T2 chip(on machines where the SMC is integrated into the T2 chip). It comes from the battery charging chip that controls the laptop charger, battery charging, and creation of PPBUS_G3H(ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip depending on the logic board part number and model). This is used for sensors. If a DC current sense sensor is reading off in diagnostics, this is a place to start looking. .
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD? PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA: What is PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA? This is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing/charging chip. This can be shorted to ground by the capacitor on its line, and when this happens, the chip can stop functioning which causes the charger to not turn on. This can also be missing if the CD3215 chip itself is bad. Each CD3215 in the system needs to be functioning in order for any of them to speak to the charger and negotiate receiving 20v from the charger rather than the default 5v that a USB-C charger puts out before communicating with the system. .
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (2017 13" MBP) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 1.1V, USB at 20V but 0.04A flowing, No Power or Charge
threads.message:
I have a 2017 13" MacBook Pro motherboard (model <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A) that won't turn on. I measured the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> line with a USB-C charger connected, and get around 1.08V (instead of 12V?). No short to ground in this line - resistance measures 1K ohms rapidly increasing to infinity.

Fuses F3000 and F3100 are both intact - I resistance tested them. However when I test for <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> (or the one for the other port) at either F3000 or F3100's terminals, I get zero volts at all. Measuring between ground and either of F3100 or F3000's terminals, I get a 22.8 ohm continuity. Is this a short to ground? How would I find this short? I see there are some adjacent capacitors, one of those?

I probed for <SIGNAL>PP20V_USBC_XA_VBUS</SIGNAL> at other adjacent points (including L3300 and L3400 solder pads - my board apparently never had these components) - no voltage at all.
Other nearby voltage rails I probed: <SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC2</SIGNAL> (and CC1 and CC1/<SIGNAL>2_CONN</SIGNAL>) fluctuating between 0.8 and 1.5V, <SIGNAL>SAVE_CC1A</SIGNAL> no voltage at all.

Anyone know what's wrong? Thanks in advance!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (2017 13" MBP) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 1.1V, USB at 20V but 0.04A flowing, No Power or Charge
threads.message:
Any history available, liquid sign?

How do you get 20V on USB-C meter with 0V at F3000/1?
What is <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> voltage?

Use diode mode to check power rails to ground.
Switch to ohm scale ONLY for very low readings; less than 0.010 usually.

"Measuring between ground and either of F3100 or F3000's terminals, I get a 22.8 ohm continuity"
STOP to check ohm scale (or diode mode) with power applied on the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (2017 13" MBP) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 1.1V, USB at 20V but 0.04A flowing, No Power or Charge
threads.message:
(I typed this a few days ago and apparently never hit Post!)

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> appears to be an SMD component who's terminals I can't access. Measuring the lines connecting to it, though, all 4 of them are at 19.98V.

With the USB-C cable connected to what would have been the rear port in the laptop, I get a reading of 382 between ground and F3000 in diode mode. Reading of infinity at F3010, and if I plug the USBC charge cable into the other port, my meter doesn't light up at all (loose connection? Or is this something to worry about?)

No reliable history on the device, but there are no signs of liquid damage (indicators are also still white). I was told this laptop worked a few months ago and sat since, and doesn't work anymore.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> test point to ground (screw hole) gives infinity reading in diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (2017 13" MBP) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 1.1V, USB at 20V but 0.04A flowing, No Power or Charge
threads.message:
"STOP to check ohm scale (or diode mode) with power applied on the board.
....................................
With the USB-C cable connected to what would have been the rear port in the laptop, I get a reading of 382 between ground and F3000 in diode mode."
Why continue doing that???

"<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> appears to be ....  at 19.98V"
That's good; you should get the same connecting charger on both ports.

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> test point to ground (screw hole) gives infinity reading in diode mode."
Read how to properly use diode mode scale (more usefull tips there).
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]

Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>*, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.
Use  surrounding components as test points; like <CAPACITOR>C7016</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7075</CAPACITOR>/77, <RESISTOR>R7071</RESISTOR>/72, etc...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (2017 13" MBP) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 1.1V, USB at 20V but 0.04A flowing, No Power or Charge
threads.message:
> Why continue doing that???
Sorry, I must have misunderstood, I thought that was one of the things you wanted me to test, when you said stop to check ohm scale or diode mode with power applied to board. By "power applied to board", did you mean the method of injecting 1V?

Measuring between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> test point and ground with diode mode as instructed in your other post, I'm getting a reading of 480. You were right, I was using it with reverse polarity. Thanks!

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages:
<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> (measured at test point and <CAPACITOR>C7016</CAPACITOR> pad - my board does not have the <CAPACITOR>C7016</CAPACITOR> component) : [B]4.26V[/B]
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL>: (measured at test point and <CAPACITOR>C7075</CAPACITOR>):[B] 5.12V[/B]
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDP</SIGNAL>: (measured at <CAPACITOR>C7077</CAPACITOR>): [B]5.12V[/B]
Very strange thing I noticed, when I had the multimeter probe touched to a screw point and <CAPACITOR>C7077</CAPACITOR> measuring that voltage, I could hear an audible ticking sound from the circuit board - even though there are no moving parts on it??)
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL> (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pin 19, measured at test point next to <CAPACITOR>C7026</CAPACITOR> and at <RESISTOR>R5439</RESISTOR>: [B]0.01V[/B]
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL> (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pin 14, measured at test point next to <CAPACITOR>C7026</CAPACITOR> and at <RESISTOR>R5438</RESISTOR>:[B] 0.00V[/B]
<SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pin 28, measured at test point next to <CAPACITOR>C7724</CAPACITOR> and at <RESISTOR>R7071</RESISTOR>: [B]3.39V[/B]
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_R_L</SIGNAL> (<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pin 39, measured at <RESISTOR>R7072</RESISTOR> and test point next to it):[B] 3.39V[/B]

I'm not sure what you mean by <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>. My schematic for the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A does not have this net at all, not at <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> or anywhere else. I measured <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> pin 34, <SIGNAL>TBA_HPWR_EN_L</SIGNAL>, at <RESISTOR>R7073</RESISTOR>: [B]3.10V[/B]. Is this what you meant?

When I measure <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>'s connections with the USB-C power cable connected to the other port, I get a reading of 1V or less continuously drifting down. My USB-C power meter also does not light up when connected to this port (the LCD on the meter flashes on for a fraction of a second every few seconds. I tried wiggling and moving the plug - no luck.

Also worth mentioning, maybe? : when I plug into the rear-side port, the one that was working semi-right, my USB-C power meter reads 0.13A coming down and stabilizing around 0.08A, instead of the 0.04 that it was reading earlier. I have made no changes to the board since my last post when it was reading 0.04A, no clue what changed.

Thank you for your time!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (2017 13" MBP) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 1.1V, USB at 20V but 0.04A flowing, No Power or Charge
threads.message:
Ball F2/<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> isn't <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>?

Both USB-C ports must have the same behavior.
If not, you have a problem on USB-C area; need to find the culprit.
Please don't make "cardinal refferences" (lef/right, front/rear, up/down); post position component on the schematic/boardview.
Also use schematic instead of boardview, when you mention component pins (especially for BGA chips).

NEVER check board in diode mode, or ohm scale with charger, or battery connected!!!

Reffering to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200, let us know the actual behavior of each port.
Compare diode mode readings on the 4 LDOS of both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (2017 13" MBP) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 1.1V, USB at 20V but 0.04A flowing, No Power or Charge
threads.message:
Found <SIGNAL>EN_VR1</SIGNAL>, as you said it's on the schematic. My boardview has it labeled as "<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>".[B] Voltage: 3.39V[/B]
The two USB-C port certainly do NOT have the same behavior. One does not even light up my power meter, and board voltages are very low (compared with what I've been posting here from the other port)

The working port is the one right next to the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>'s, and the non-working one is right next to component L2950.

Port A (to <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>) is not functional at all (power meter only blinks on every few seconds, 0.3 or no volts at all test points that you mentioned.
Port B (to <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>) is partially functional, giving the voltages I have mentioned so far on all the test points you mentioned. 0.07-0.08A current flow as measured by USB-C power meter.
Machine does not power on on either port.

LDO readings are as follows:
<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (with cable connected to corresponding port):
<SIGNAL>LDO_3V3</SIGNAL> (pin G1, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XB_LDO</SIGNAL>): [B]3.32V[/B]
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8A</SIGNAL> (pin K1, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOA</SIGNAL>): [B]1.79V[/B]
<SIGNAL>LDO_1V8D</SIGNAL> (pin A2, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_UPC_XB_LDOD</SIGNAL>): [B]1.78V[/B]
<SIGNAL>LDO_BMS</SIGNAL> (pin E1, <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XB_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>): [B]1.11V[/B]
(All voltages are zero with USB-C connected to other - <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> - port. Expected?)

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (with cable connected to corresponding port: ALL 4 LDO voltages are [B]zero volts.[/B]

Can an issue with <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>'s circuit cause <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>'s circuit also to not work?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A (2017 13" MBP) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 1.1V, USB at 20V but 0.04A flowing, No Power or Charge
threads.message:
SMC needs to talk with both <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 chips.

"Compare diode mode readings on the 4 LDOs of both <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips."
???

Check diode mode to ground on CC1/2 pins of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.
Also inspect the terminals of the non-working USB-C port (possibly corrosion).
And test both ports in both connection ways; 4 combinations in total.
